Noted Biologist Speaks On
Travel and Politics In
Tropical Africa
NEARLY 1,000 PEOPLE
CRAM LECTURE ROOM
Makes Use Of Slides To Exhibit
Strange Natural Wonders
Of Backward Country
In Africa orchids are red, temperate forests are to be found in
the higher regions, and queen termites, or white ants, lay an egg
every three and a half seconds, declared Julian Huxley, biologist, author, professor, and lecturer, in an
illustrated lecture to the largest
crowd to throng .the lecture hall in
the C. E. Building since Dr. Millikan spoke there last year. It was
estimated that between eight hundren and a thousand were present.
Fifteen minutes before the lecture began all the seats were occupied, and at 5 o'clock the standing
space was overtaxed. Huxley and
Professor Lancaster, his host, had
to push through the crowds that
stood around title door to get to the
platform.

After working hard all week correcting last Saturday's mistakes,
the Hopkins football team is ready
to lock horns with their annual
rivals, St. John's College of Annapolis. The game, which is to be
played at Homewood Field tonight
at 8 o'clock, promises to be one of
the greatest battles in the history
of the two schools.
Football fans throughout the
State as well as the majority of
sports writers in the city seem to
take it for granted that the Jays
are outclassed even before they go
on the field. Surprises in football
are ever present. In the HopkinsSt. John's games they are expected.
There is a great possibility that one
of these surprises will be displayed
tonight.

Nine men of the Colgate University of Bethlehem, Pa., have been
sleeping nightly on vibrating beds
and discovering unexpected ways
in which a machine age may cause
headaches, circled eyes, and unsociable dispositions. As could be expected, the psychology department
of the school is sponsoring the tests,
to find the effects of noise and vibrations on sleepers.
* * * * *
Students of Cambridge University at Cambridge, England, have
discovered a new sport, according
to the Williamette Collegian. It consists of placing wagers on the
length of the sermons preached in
the various local churches each
Sunday. A regular system of handicaps and odds has been developed
from observations of the sermons
from week to week. The long
shots, to use racing parlance, are
the guest preachers from out-oftown churches, whose past performances are unknown quantities.

Bloodgood Proposes Plan
For Prevention Of Cancer

An influence for
better dressing at
Maryland colleges!

Presents Views at American Public
Health Association Meeting Held
In Fort Worth

At a meeting of the American
Public Health Association in Fort
Worth, Texas, recently, Dr. Joseph
C. Bloodgood, Professor of Clinical Surgery at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School proposed a new
plan for the prevention of cancer.
He suggested that each State organize through its health board,
universities and health societies, a
program of education and health
clinics to fight the disease.
Dr. Bloodgood declared that
since there is no cure in sight, there
could be no effective protection
against mortality from the disease
except by education for its prevention.
He pointed out that the State
would not encroach upon private
medical practice through its educational program. For those who
could not afford periodic health examinations clinics would have to be
provided to carry out this program
of education in detail.
He concluded that certain forms
of cancer such as cancer of the
mouth and skin are known to be
preventable, and also that cancer in
women could be prevented by periodic health examinations.

THE ST. JOHNS GAME
TONIGHT the Johns Hopkins football eleven faces a difficult
1- task. It meets a good football team which has been preparing for
this contest for three weeks. St. Johns had no game last Saturday,
and a very easy game two weeks ago. Furthermore, Hopkins is the
big objective for the Johnies, and they have had this game in mind
all year. Hopkins, on the other hand, has not had a let up all
season, and meets its principal rival less than two weeks hence. The
St. Johns team is keyed up for the game to a man. The Jays have
Maryland to think about. The Annapolis team is supposedly stronger
than the Homewood eleven. The outlook indeed seems black. Victory, however, may be achieved if each member of the team is on the
alert each minute and gives his best performance. The Jays exhibited a
strong offense against Haverford. A similar offense would surely
score on the Johnies, and if the defense plays the game it is capable
of, Hopkins should win. We wish to take this opportunity to wish
the eleven the best of luck, and assure them what we believe a victory will be achieved if they play the type of football that has occasionally ben exhibited this season.

Those students connected with the 'Stormers are working harder
to mind.
than any other activities men. This brings two thoughts
In the first place, the dramatic organization deserves the full support
of the student body. The Lyric should be crowded both nights of the
annual production. In the second place, it seems rather futile that
all this work should be done for only two evenings. If this year's
play shows a large enough audience, it might be possible for the
Barnstormers to take a road trip. Other college dramatic organizations are able to do this, and although there are many difficulties in
the path, we believe that the Hopkins organization could also give
performances out of town. First, however, it is necessary that the
home performance be a financial success. We hope that all students
will do their best to make it so.

Discusses Soviet Russia

At the meeting of the Cosmopolitan Club in Levering Hall last Saturday, Dr. J. M. Mathern led a
round table discussion about Soviet
Russia. At first the Russian students answered questions about the
present state of affairs in Soviet
Russia. There seemed to be a great
difference of opinion according to
their sympathies.
The non-Russian students were
then asked their opinion concerning
the recognition of Soviet Russia by
the United States. All were in
favor except one student who
comes from Central Europe.
The discussion was quite animated and lasted until a late hour
in the evening. Mr. Eng, a student
from China, furnished a humorous
characterization of certain members
of the club.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 14, 1930

J. CLARK COMMENTS
ON RUSSIAN POLICY
Hopkins Grad Student Presents Views At Assembly
RESOURCES CONSERVED
Claims Russian Economic Institutions Are Sound
"The Russian Government is
fundamentally sound, as far as stability is determined by popular
opinion", was the view expressed
by Mr. John D. Clark, in his address at the student assembly yesterday. Mr. Clark is a graduate
student at the Hopkins, and will
assume the position of professor
of economics at the University of
Denver next year. He was also
president of the Midwestern Refining Company and is consequently an authority on industrial conditions.
Investigated Conditions

The party of twenty-five professional, academic and social economists, in which Mr. Clark was included, arrived at a conclusion concerning the Russian situation
which, by his own admission, is
contrary to most reports: "Although anomalies are present here
and there, which is to be expected
in so great a venture, substantial
progress under the new plan is
evident."
In order to understand the situation, Mr. Clark asserted, a knowledge of the history of Russia was
necessary. He told how a civil war
which accompanied the rise of
Lenin, and a drought which followed immediately upon it was responsible for the complete demise
of Russian industry. Thus, according to Mr. Clark, "it was not
the government that was responsible for unfavorable reports of Russia, but rather the lack of one."
The Five Year Plan

When the war was over, it was
essental for the ruling party, the
Communists, to provide an effective plan for the rebuilding of the
industrial system. This precipitated
the five year plan, which was hailed
by economists as the mot ambitious plan for the rebuilding of industry ever known. It provided
for the expenditure of thirty-three
billion dollars in the space of three
years, for the construction of
plants having as great an output as
the foremost American factories.
The raising of money presented
the greatest obstacle to the successful operation of the plan. Russia
was in a state of financial ruin.
Her credit was nil, there was no
accumulation of money in the
country, and the only mode of revenue that was open to her was the
exportation of natural resources in
which she abounds.
Rigid Economy Urged

The government, consequently,
asked the people to refrain, as
much as possible, from overconsumption of simple necessities so
that a greater quantity would be
available for exportation. That
the people were willing to undergo
these privations in the interest of a
governmental scheme is a fact that
Mr. Clark considers especially significant. "The people are hungry
but they are not starving", he
averred. "If the govenment desired, it could clothe and feed its
workers in comparative luxury,
but the funds are being used for
reindustrialization."
General Conditions

Aside from economic strife, the
situation in Russia is as good as
anywhere else. The worker's cities
which are built up around the
large plants are admirably equipped
for every need of the individual.
Police protection is completely organized and life is safer in Russia
than in Chicago, Mr. Clark assures
us, if one keeps out of politics.

OURTH down! Seconds to play! Defending a slender onepoint margin of victory, eleven husky bodies have valiantly
repulsed three smashing attacks which have advanced the ball a
scant foot to the fifteen-yard line. With success almost certainly
within the defender's grasp, the field goal specialist drops far back
behind his stalwart line. A crashing impact — a blur of rushing
bodies — and his nimble foot sends the ball high between the goal
posts for the winning points!
Shift this scene to a battle ground of modern business. The goal
is an important contract... a substantial order for equipment or
appliances. Salesmanship, backed by a product of established
quality, plays its important part; but a Westinghouse representative is more than a salesman. The background of specialized engineering skill that enables him to serve his customers as a consultant
in electrification is what supplies the necessary "punch" to win.
To many a younger college man with Westinghouse has come
the opportunity to apply his talent toward the conclusion of a
worthwhile transaction. The young men whose photographs
appear on this page are but a few of the many who, with college
only a few years behind them,are finding success with an organization offering such a variety of opportunities in the world's electrical work.

In Africa orchids are red, temperate forests are to be found in

crowd to throng .the lecture hall in
the C. E. Building since Dr. Millikan spoke there last year. It was
estimated that between eight hundren and a thousand were present.

space was overtaxed. Huxley and
Professor Lancaster, his host, had
to push through the crowds that
stood around title door to get to the
platform.

Nine men of the Colgate University of Bethlehem, Pa., have been
sleeping nightly on vibrating beds
and discovering unexpected ways
in which a machine age may cause
headaches, circled eyes, and unsociable dispositions. As could be expected, the psychology department
of the school is sponsoring the tests,
to find the effects of noise and vibrations on sleepers.

discovered a new sport, according
to the Williamette Collegian. It consists of placing wagers on the
length of the sermons preached in
the various local churches each
Sunday. A regular system of handicaps and odds has been developed
from observations of the sermons
from week to week. The long
shots, to use racing parlance, are
the guest preachers from out-oftown churches, whose past performances are unknown quantities.

Bloodgood Proposes Plan
For Prevention Of Cancer

An influence for
better dressing at
Maryland colleges!

Presents Views at American Public
Health Association Meeting Held
In Fort Worth

At a meeting of the American
Public Health Association in Fort
Worth, Texas, recently, Dr. Joseph
C. Bloodgood, Professor of Clinical Surgery at the Johns Hopkins
Medical School proposed a new
plan for the prevention of cancer.
He suggested that each State organize through its health board,
universities and health societies, a
program of education and health
clinics to fight the disease.
Dr. Bloodgood declared that
since there is no cure in sight, there
could be no effective protection
against mortality from the disease
except by education for its prevention.
He pointed out that the State
would not encroach upon private
medical practice through its educational program. For those who
could not afford periodic health examinations clinics would have to be
provided to carry out this program
of education in detail.
He concluded that certain forms
of cancer such as cancer of the
mouth and skin are known to be
preventable, and also that cancer in
women could be prevented by periodic health examinations.

THE ST. JOHNS GAME
TONIGHT the Johns Hopkins football eleven faces a difficult
1- task. It meets a good football team which has been preparing for
this contest for three weeks. St. Johns had no game last Saturday,
and a very easy game two weeks ago. Furthermore, Hopkins is the
big objective for the Johnies, and they have had this game in mind
all year. Hopkins, on the other hand, has not had a let up all
season, and meets its principal rival less than two weeks hence. The
St. Johns team is keyed up for the game to a man. The Jays have
Maryland to think about. The Annapolis team is supposedly stronger
than the Homewood eleven. The outlook indeed seems black. Victory, however, may be achieved if each member of the team is on the
alert each minute and gives his best performance. The Jays exhibited a
strong offense against Haverford. A similar offense would surely
score on the Johnies, and if the defense plays the game it is capable
of, Hopkins should win. We wish to take this opportunity to wish
the eleven the best of luck, and assure them what we believe a victory will be achieved if they play the type of football that has occasionally ben exhibited this season.

In the first place, the dramatic organization deserves the full support

Discusses Soviet Russia

At the meeting of the Cosmopolitan Club in Levering Hall last Saturday, Dr. J. M. Mathern led a
round table discussion about Soviet
Russia. At first the Russian students answered questions about the
present state of affairs in Soviet
Russia. There seemed to be a great
difference of opinion according to
their sympathies.
The non-Russian students were
then asked their opinion concerning
the recognition of Soviet Russia by
the United States. All were in
favor except one student who
comes from Central Europe.
The discussion was quite animated and lasted until a late hour
in the evening. Mr. Eng, a student
from China, furnished a humorous
characterization of certain members
of the club.

Season Starts December 13

The season will open on December 13 instead of on the 6th, as had
previously been decided, due to the
Maryland-Western Maryland football tilt scheduled for the latter date.
Play will be conducted on Saturdays and Sundays throughout December, January and February at
the Fifth Regiment Armory. The
regular matches will be preceded by
practice matches. All teams will
pay their own expenses.
This tournament will be followed
by the State Senior, the Evening
Sun Junior and Boys and the
Women's State tournaments.
This winter indoor practice is expected to improve the calibre of the
Hopkins team, and to prepare them
for the spring season. Manager Lebow is .compiling an attractive
spring schedule which will include
teams from some of the larger
Eastern universities.
As a result of the whole-hearted
support rendered by the student
body in signing the tennis ballots,
spring will find the Hopkins campus graced by newly reconditioned
courts.

SWIMMING
Some forty men, present at a
meeting held last Thursday, gave
Coach Hambleton and Manager
Warlow of the swimming team an
optimistic outlook on the impending season.
Arrangements have been made
for the use of the Knights of Columbus pool by the Jay natators.
Practice is destined to start immediately following the Thanksgiving
recess, and will be limited to Wednesday and Friday afternoons, at
4.30. Due to additional demand
for it, the management was able to
secure the pool for only two days
instead of the customary three.
This reduction in the number of
practices will be hard felt and will
result in a necessity for added work
on the part of the coach as well as
the men.
During the month of December,
Coach Hambleton expects to be
able to select his varsity and freshman squads.

Among the new material that is
expected to report for practice, are
two divers, "Bill" Reid and "Pick"
Temple, both of whom are, at present, directing their attentions to
football. The breast stroke should
be bolstered by Steam, New York
City champion in that event while
at George Washington High School
of New York. Boyce made good
time in the '220' while at Tome, and
Charles Squire held down a regular back stroke job on a crack Central High team, of Washington,
D. C.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 14, 1930

J. CLARK COMMENTS
ON RUSSIAN POLICY
Hopkins Grad Student Presents Views At Assembly
RESOURCES CONSERVED
Claims Russian Economic Institutions Are Sound
"The Russian Government is
fundamentally sound, as far as stability is determined by popular
opinion", was the view expressed
by Mr. John D. Clark, in his address at the student assembly yesterday. Mr. Clark is a graduate
student at the Hopkins, and will
assume the position of professor
of economics at the University of
Denver next year. He was also
president of the Midwestern Refining Company and is consequently an authority on industrial conditions.
Investigated Conditions

The party of twenty-five professional, academic and social economists, in which Mr. Clark was included, arrived at a conclusion concerning the Russian situation
which, by his own admission, is
contrary to most reports: "Although anomalies are present here
and there, which is to be expected
in so great a venture, substantial
progress under the new plan is
evident."
In order to understand the situation, Mr. Clark asserted, a knowledge of the history of Russia was
necessary. He told how a civil war
which accompanied the rise of
Lenin, and a drought which followed immediately upon it was responsible for the complete demise
of Russian industry. Thus, according to Mr. Clark, "it was not
the government that was responsible for unfavorable reports of Russia, but rather the lack of one."
The Five Year Plan

When the war was over, it was
essental for the ruling party, the
Communists, to provide an effective plan for the rebuilding of the
industrial system. This precipitated
the five year plan, which was hailed
by economists as the mot ambitious plan for the rebuilding of industry ever known. It provided
for the expenditure of thirty-three
billion dollars in the space of three
years, for the construction of
plants having as great an output as
the foremost American factories.
The raising of money presented
the greatest obstacle to the successful operation of the plan. Russia
was in a state of financial ruin.
Her credit was nil, there was no
accumulation of money in the
country, and the only mode of revenue that was open to her was the
exportation of natural resources in
which she abounds.
Rigid Economy Urged

The government, consequently,
asked the people to refrain, as
much as possible, from overconsumption of simple necessities so
that a greater quantity would be
available for exportation. That
the people were willing to undergo
these privations in the interest of a
governmental scheme is a fact that
Mr. Clark considers especially significant. "The people are hungry
but they are not starving", he
averred. "If the govenment desired, it could clothe and feed its
workers in comparative luxury,
but the funds are being used for
reindustrialization."
General Conditions

Aside from economic strife, the
situation in Russia is as good as
anywhere else. The worker's cities
which are built up around the
large plants are admirably equipped
for every need of the individual.
Police protection is completely organized and life is safer in Russia
than in Chicago, Mr. Clark assures
us, if one keeps out of politics.

HULLABALOO PICTURES
TO BE TAKEN MONDAY
Robert Miller, business
manager of the Hullabaloo,
today announced that additional pictures will be taken
for the annual starting Monday, November 17. The
schedule follows:
Monday-12.20, A. A.
Board; 12.30, Varsity Club;
12.45, NEWS-LETTER staff;
4.00, R. 0. T. C.; 4.30, Band.
Tuesday-12.20, Interfraternity Board; 12.30, Student
Activities Council; 12.45, Cotillion Board; 4.00, Black and
Blue Jay staff; 4.15, A. S. M.
E.
Wednesday-12.20, Junior
class; 12.30, Senior class; 4,
A. S. C. E.; 4.15, Electrical
Club; 4.30, Gas Engineers'
Association.
"All Seniors who have not
had their photographs taken
should sign up immediately
for their sittings," announced
Miller. "The Hullabaloo office will continue to be open
for these for one or two days,
and promptness is urgently
requested."

OURTH down! Seconds to play! Defending a slender onepoint margin of victory, eleven husky bodies have valiantly
repulsed three smashing attacks which have advanced the ball a
scant foot to the fifteen-yard line. With success almost certainly
within the defender's grasp, the field goal specialist drops far back
behind his stalwart line. A crashing impact — a blur of rushing
bodies — and his nimble foot sends the ball high between the goal
posts for the winning points!
Shift this scene to a battle ground of modern business. The goal
is an important contract... a substantial order for equipment or
appliances. Salesmanship, backed by a product of established
quality, plays its important part; but a Westinghouse representative is more than a salesman. The background of specialized engineering skill that enables him to serve his customers as a consultant
in electrification is what supplies the necessary "punch" to win.
To many a younger college man with Westinghouse has come
the opportunity to apply his talent toward the conclusion of a
worthwhile transaction. The young men whose photographs
appear on this page are but a few of the many who, with college
only a few years behind them,are finding success with an organization offering such a variety of opportunities in the world's electrical work.
